etymologies: mid 19th century; earliest use found in Reports of the British Association for the Advancement of Science. From ancient Greek ὁμαλός even, level, equal + -graphic, after French homalographique

definitions: Designating a method of projection in which equal areas on the earth's surface are represented by equal areas on a map or chart; (of a map or chart) produced using such a method.

notes.text: Although there are several kinds of equal-area projection, the term homalographic is associated especially with Mollweide's projection.
